name: pregn-5-en-20-yne-3,17-diol
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4220
Reason: 1,1'-Terphenyl has a melting point of 205.0 degrees Celsius. The compound pregn-5-en-20-yne-3,17-diol has a melting point that is influenced by the functional groups present in the molecule relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5.5 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of pregn-5-en-20-yne-3,17-diol, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the presence of a diol group can contribute to hydrogen bonding, which can further increase the melting point by approximately +20°C.
